title.narrative: Train the trainers on United Nation Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1325 on Women, Peace, and Security (WPS) in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The organisation's goals are to empower Afghan women and promote their rights and status in the Afghan society by facilitating their meaningful participation in national reconstruction and peace building, and promoting the enjoyment of their rights as human beings.
The organisation requests a Tailor Made Training (TMT) for its staff to enhance their knowledge and understanding of United Nation Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1325 on Women, Peace, and Security (WPS), and effective advocacy and communication. As a result of this training women activists will be equipped with the substantive knowledge and skills required for their meaningful participation in conflict prevention and peace building in the local, national, and international levels.
The Tailor Made Training can solve the knowledge and skills problems as follows:
- Improving the knowledge of the staff members to understand the definition, concepts and approaches of United Nation Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1325 on Women, Peace, and Security (WPS) - Improving the knowledge and skills of the staff in effective advocacy and communication with focus on advocacy activities on human rights/ women’s rights. - Improving the soft skills of women staff members and activists on their commitment, motivation, and self-esteem while dealing with male members of the society, particularly in the rural areas. - Enhance the skills in 'training of trainers (TOT) of our staff members so that they can replicate their knowledge and expertise to our partners and target groups effectively. - The training subjects which we propose are the following: Women, Peace, and Security, Effective advocacy and communication, Training of Trainers
​

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form.
